DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Vinyl acetate monomer was removed from this facility

_chemical.ChemicalName: Vinyl acetate monomer  [Acetic acid ethenyl ester]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility:  This facility uses OPA 90 - Oil Pollution Act (33 CFR 154) and SPCC (40 CFR 112) rules to manage the release prevention and emergency response activities.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  If any emergency were to occur, it is our policy to follow the emergency procedures outlined in our 2003 Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP).  The procedures in our ICP include shutting down as promptly as possible the operation and notifying the Terminal Manager and the United States Coast Guard.  The ICP is discussed in further detail in the emergency response program section below.

A description of your facility and the regulated substances handled:  This facility manages liquid and bulk transfer of chemicals.  We receive and ship material by water, rail and truck.  The facility manages the regulated substance, vinyl acetate monomer.  The vinyl acetate monomer is stored in one 860,627-gallon storage tank, which is limited to 90% capacity by an internal floating roof.  

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:  This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule, OPA 90 - Oil Pollution Act (33 CFR 154), SPCC (40 CFR 112), and all applicable state a local codes and regulations.  Furthermore, the vinyl acetate system is maintained in accordance with good engineering practice.

Five-year accident history:  Queen City Termincal, Inc. has not had an accident involving vinyl acetate that caused injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place in the past five years.

The emergency response program:  In the event of an emergency involving our vinly acetate process, it is our policy to follow the guidelines outlined in our ICP.  The ICP includes, but is not limited to, our SPCC Plan, Contingency and Response planning, and Emergency Action Plan.  The ICP is intended for the

protection of the employees of Queen City Terminal, Inc. and our neighbors surrounding our plant.  The plan ensures that the most efficient methods of response by certified individuals can take place during a possible accident.  

Among other things, the ICP covers emergency response actions, internal and external notification procedures and sequences, facility spill mitigation procedures, facility response activities, disposal plan, training, drills, and plan update procedures.  The plan is intended as a reference source to familiarize the United States Coast Guard (USCG), local emergency response agencies, environmental agencies, and fire and police departments on operations at Queen City's facility.

In the event of a chemical emergency at the Queen City facility, the general manager, the USCG, and the police and fire departments are notified immediately.  There are secondary contacts in the event that the general manager is not immediately available.  The secondary contacts have complete authority to commit all resources of the company to carry out emergency response actions in the event of an emergency.  The contigency plan contains a contact list that includes the USCG, the police department, the Ohio EPA, the fire department and, emergency response contractors.

Planned changes to improve safety: None.
